criticReviews.criticPost: Though hiccups and growing pains are evident on the screen, the series still knows how to deliver terrific action sequences and that should be enough to keep longtime fans around as this latest iteration figures itself out.
The serialized narrative, which breaks up the action into smaller missions within a larger story, is a return to form for HBO-owned Cinemax.
Based on the six episodes Cinemax sent out for review in advance of Friday night's premiere, it's in many ways the Strike Back fans knew and loved the first time out.
I have very much enjoyed this show, which has always exuded an intelligence that made it both enjoyably substantial and emotionally engaging. But all good things must come to an end.
Those violent altercations, fun action sequences, and general sense of adventure are why people tune in to Strike Back and the show doesn't need to be more than that.

Perhaps the most appealing thing about Strike Back, at least on a subliminal level, is its utter lack of moral equivalence. Good is good and bad is bad and nobody's going to force you to feel guilty about any gray areas.
Strike Back is the kind of show that blends effortless cool with unrelenting action.
Once the action starts, as usual, it rarely lets up.
Scenes of quiet only serve to bridge action sequences. Our heroes move from one shoot-up to the next. The biggest item in the show's budget has to be for squibs.

It's a shame that Strike Back is leaving us with when it still feels capable of shouldering a few more world-ending crises, but it's going into its ending with gas in the tank and its clips fully loaded.
It incorporates the look and spirit of video games and violent comic books into a television series as well as any show around.
I say it every season of Strike Back, and every season it's true: They've topped themselves again ... The final season is well worth the wait.
Damien Scott and Michael "Mikey" Stonebridge are action heroes to the max-the Cinemax, more specifically, mascots of mayhem for HBO's pulp companion network.
Strike Back's primary goal isn't to tell a story, it's to show-off the always entertaining relationship of its characters, particularly that of Michael Stonebridge and Damien Scott.
The show is way more than a thriller?although it could stand tall if it were just that.
This spook is obviously right, but as long as the ammo holds up, Strike Back isn't going anywhere.
The show is well-plotted, tightly paced and crisply edited.

If something has been missing from your TV screen since 24 went off the air, like an unapologetic, fist-pumping, nonstop action thriller, Strike Back needs to be your appointment television for the next 10 weeks.
Fans of 24 still ask me how to fill that void. They want just enough intelligence-agency hooey to make the unbelievable seem somewhat real. Until Strike Back, I didn't have a good answer. Now I do.
There is nothing really new here, but that doesn't mean the series doesn't work.
Strike Back isn't brilliant television, but it's plenty entertaining, and by fitting the action of 24 with the grit of The Unit, it fills a .22 caliber hole in American television.
Strike Back unfolds quickly and confidently with brilliantly choreographed fight sequences and the exotic locales. But nothing trumps the friendship of the two male leads.
Strike Back is a stylish, addictive action thriller that fills a definite void in the macho spy drama genre.
Strike Back won't make anyone forget 24 or MI-5 or even The Unit, but it has its pleasures for the aficionado of guns and flesh in exotic locales.
Notwithstanding the show's lurches into unintended farce-there'lll be more than enough raw-nerve action, bullets to the head and near catastrophes to keep viewers happy to the end.
It offers no obviously considered commentary on today's wars or geopolitical conditions. It's more a videogame, where war occurs because that's simply how things are.
Strip away the counterterrorism lingo and this is really just a mismatched buddy copshow.
Gratuitous elements aside, Strike Back is a decent enough cops 'n' terrorists drama.
Tom Burke's Strike is the perfect lost genius posh boy and Holliday Grainger's Robin, his sidekick, is exactly as much in love with him as she needs to be to keep things ticking along.
Holliday Grainger, who plays Robin, and Tom Burke as private investigator Cormoran Strike are fast becoming the will-they-won't-they item de nos jours.

he return to Sunday nights of Robert Galbraith's thoroughly likable if unlikely private detective pairing is good news. They have about three quid in the company coffers, plus a soupcon of sexual chemistry.
This two-parter has a grisly plot, but the secret to its success is the winning chemistry between Tom Burke and Holliday Grainger.
Strike, based on JK Rowling's "Robert Galbraith" murder-mysteries, returns for a second series, and it's no less improbable or convoluted than the first.
Strike manages to be modern yet old-fashioned, discomfiting yet cosy, absurd yet plausible. If you ask me we've found our next great TV detective.
In a world with Sherlock, Dirk Gently and other sundry nonsense, this occasionally threatens to be bland, but generally pulls back to a level of quality instead.
Strike remains tame and civilised: the direction shockingly slow, the sex scenes perfunctory, the violence at a remove.
It was an entertaining stagger through the seedy world of dodgy contacts, dark pool halls, greasy caffs, family dysfunctionality and hairs of the dog.
Now that was a pleasure.
The whole gumshoe shtick feels supremely dated, as does the lame dialogue, as does the storytelling.
The show tries to repackage a 450-page murder mystery, full of different characters and back stories into three one-hour episodes - and does so to a good degree of success.
As late summer fare goes -- maybe that should read "fayre" in the circumstances -- The Cuckoo's Calling is perfectly enjoyable.
This adaptation works hard to maintain a balance between raw authenticity and the hokier demands of the genre.

As with the book, I'm not sure I would have been so drawn to it if it hadn't been for Rowling's name. But such is the wonder of branding. Now that I'm here I can see myself sticking around for the long term.
Among its most memorable touches: theme music based on a tune by Franz Schubert. Prime time can claim its occasional bit of class.
Solid docu probes 2016 election, tries to be unbiased.
Whatever terrible revolution we're watching, it definitely isn't being televised with analysis and curiosity here.

Unlike coverage on Fox News or MSNBC, The Circus offers truly objective analysis of the campaigns. It also shows a more human side of the candidates, painting a clear picture of how grueling life is on the campaign trail.
The Circus is an elegant, intimate, frequently funny look at a process that lives up to the show's title, but like most political coverage these days, leaves a brutal hangover.

The Circus is a kind of reassuring sanity break for politics nerds. There may be treacherous currents roiling this election, unknowable changes to come. But for one sharp half-hour every week, it's all just a show.
The election season show I'm most enjoying is Showtime's The Circus: Inside the Greatest Political Show on Earth.

If anything The Circus represents merely another example of exalting the process of politics - the long bus trips, time spent time away from home and strategizing - without offering much that's new or compelling in terms of substance.
We're still only at the beginning stages. All the more reason to treasure an enterprise that preserves the small details as The Circus does.
It's by far the most cleverly shaped and enlightening coverage of U.S. politics right now.
Halperin and Heilemann, authors of the best-sellers Game Change and Double Down, certainly know their stuff, even if they inject themselves a little too enthusiastically into the proceedings.
Watching the show made me ache for the kind of candid, outraged political reportage that simply doesn't exist anymore.
Actually showing racism up close would probably give viewers too much discomfort. But the invisible resolution of Abigail's storyline provides too much easy comfort.
The value of Turn was that it showed 21st century Americans how the patriots of the founding generation were just like us, for better and for worse. And that should give us hope.
Simcoe has truly turned into a comic book villain, complete with a childhood trauma-laden backstory.
It was an eventful finale that started out slow but built to an interesting conclusion.
As a fan, more Revolution-era intrigue is welcome, but the show was also very careful to tie up most all of the loose ends.

I have criticized Peggy this season for crying and moping too frequently, but her steely gaze as her man stood with a rope around his neck had me finally feeling sorry for her (and tearing up myself).
If anything, the Turn version [of events] is too short.
I'm not saying this plot twist will get me on board but it certainly made me more curious about what comes next than the series ever did in its earliest episodes.
This remains an intelligent, well-made drama that wants to get most of the history right, or at least not adulterate it too much.
Turn is back with a new subtitle, a generally quicker pace, and a greater sense of mission.

Turn could become a far more fun show in its second season thanks to the appearance of Owain Yeoman as Benedict Arnold, a character that best represents Turn's opportunity to turn foregone conclusions into riveting television.
Even the accents... promote the sense that we are peeking behind the curtain of life as it really happened, not watching another gimcrack re-creation of the bandaged head, flute and limp sort.

Despite unflinching bursts of violence... the suspense is tempered by the setting and a realization how long the war will drag on, transforming some of the caper aspects into Mission: Impossible (the series, not the movies) in powered wigs and red coats.
Turn: Season One is a great start for a show filled with exciting intrigue and compelling, character-driven drama.
I found myself enjoying the show much more than I had expected, given its questionable pedigree and the frosty reception it had received from most quarters.
Turn gets points for bringing history to the small screen and shedding light on a little-known benchmark in American espionage.
AMC's newest drama, Turn, brims with intrigue but is subpar with its execution for the first hour.

The show is done well enough that it will appease the target audience, like fans of the HBO's miniseries John Adams, but for everyone else there probably needs to be more hooks that propel the story and keep viewers interested in what comes next.
The problematic nature of TURN does not arise from its absence of fantastical creatures and places, but from the lack of any kind of charisma from its leading cast.
There's a lot to like about Turn, especially if you enjoy spy stories and are perhaps a bit of a history buff.
Turn should be a lot more exciting than it is.
Bell, who started out as a child actor, has matured into a compelling leading man and he seems capable of conveying Abraham's troubling journey into the underbelly of the war effort.
Thomas Paine described the first year of the American Revolution as the times that try men's souls. Turn simply tries our patience.
It's a good old-fashioned historical action drama in which the bad guys are clearly marked - they're wearing red! - and the stakes are as high as they get (life, liberty, etc.).
Instead, I'll turn the channel to HBO's Game of Thrones, a show about a fictional rebellion with more at stake than the creators of Turn can locate in a real one.
Turn isn't up to that standard. It's an ordinary look at an exceptional time in history.
Everything is in place for a rip-roaring good drama - except that magic spark that makes it all gell.
Plodding in its predictability and colorless in its characterizations of rebellious heroes and stock redcoat villains. [A] stubbornly bland potboiler.
[Turn] reveals a more intimate, personal side of the brutal Revolutionary War than we learned in History class.
Turn isn't bad, but it's also too forgettable to deserve a long look, cool credits or no.
Dull and sometimes confusing -- why are those British soldiers loyal to the Red Coats not wearing red? -- the 90-minute premiere too often encourages viewers to turn away in boredom or frustration.

It helps that the show is well-acted, and that everything from the fonts to the costumes to the camerawork are gorgeous. You may need a while to puzzle out what's happening on screen, but at least you can enjoy some lovely scenery.
In execution, Turn is plodding, predictable and a bit confusing, though I might have tried harder to follow the plot had any of the characters made it worth my while.
Delightful, under-the-radar and a real treasure, People of Earth is a series you should seek out.
What makes People of Earth stand out from the rest of peak TV's comedy surplus is its adept use of the ensemble dynamic.
It's not a show that traffics in big moves or over-the-top jokes, but it's all the more enjoyable for its devotion to dry, character-driven comedy.
For a sci-fi goof, People of Earth is nicely plotted, but its real attraction is the dynamic among the ensemble.
People of Earth is worth watching. It's funny and weird and the acting is great. And I want to see it get more space to do all the things it's trying to accomplish.
In these uncertain, divisive times, People of Earth could be the ultimate bonding experience.

What's also notable about this comedy, which is more clever and thought-provoking than it is gut-busting, is its focus on the notion that there's something not quite right about our world and it's making some folks unstable.
Quirky alien abduction comedy is funny, sometimes silly.
The show has a solid amount of humor, but ultimately, comedy is a background tool for a show that deals with topics like trauma, empathy, and trust.
Both its humor and its more serious themes feel undernourished, and the end result is a comedy that, despite its potential, feels slight.
It's gently funny, but also endearing.
The whole thing is from Conan O'Brien and Greg Daniels (The Office), so the jokes are dry and funny.

People of Earth succeeds with a combination of a strong ensemble cast led by Wyatt Cenac and Ana Gasteyer, a sweet tonality throughout that blends tragedy and eccentric humor, and an endearing plot arc.

Borrowing the support group concept from The Bob Newhart Show and Dear John and injecting it with aliens results in People of Earth a funny, bizarre high concept comedy about a support group for alien abductees.
In spite of Cenac's Ozzie, this is truly an ensemble vehicle with everyone getting a chance to shine here.

Great comedies have a rhythm that make them more than the sum of their parts. While there may be enough quality parts here to warrant a look, in today's crowded TV marketplace, those pieces don't come together enough to make the show stand out.
It manages to be sweet, smart, quirky, story-strong and funny all at the same time with what appears to be minimal effort.

While Cenac's patented deadpan affect produces plenty of laughs when he's paired with any of his fellow experiencers, People's funniest scenes are the ones featuring the very peculiar Earth-invading aliens.
Initially silly, then sublime comedy explores meaning and connection. Even aliens are only human.
It just needs to work on the balance between making us care about the actual people of earth and making us laugh. Once they find that... they should have a winner.
There are a lot of bells and whistles to People Of Earth, but at its core, it's a show about making first contact -- between humanity and extraterrestrials, and between humanity and itself.
People of Earth has the right instincts.
The slight but appealing People of Earth... is a contemporary anti-comedy or semi-comedy with a traditional sitcom core.

What transpires isn't a 'ha ha funny' comedy, but rather a humorous and interesting look at the many ways people try to hide from their true selves when some aspects of real life are just too messy or painful to fully embrace.
Four seasons in, it's starting to become clear that when weirdos bond, they bond hard. And in a most wonderfully entertaining way.
The show still puts us in a position where we can't help but root for [Pam].
For so many shows the introduction of babies is a death sentence. In this case, however, it adds something that always makes The Last Man on Earth its best: high stakes.
The gang, now with two more members, can finally set sail for a brighter tomorrow.

Like watching two sea-doos slowly arcing through the ocean on an unlikely, yet inevitable collision course, The Last Man on Earth Season 4 premiere offered a few tantalizing possibilities, but ultimately felt stuck on a predictable path.
There's still not much happening .
It's an unexpected move for the show to take, though given the high concept we've started with, not one that's too far out of the ordinary.
The hour-long finale didn't quite match the height of its ending, but it did set up a future worth rooting for.
As its fans well know, The Last Man On Earth is everything a comedy is supposed to be - funny, vibrant, creative. It also has a superpower few sitcoms can claim: a mean sucker-punch to the gut.
Things take a gloriously dangerous, unexpected turn that drastically shakes up the show's status quo and the lives of these people.
The best part about LMOE is its ability to switch things up on a dime while always relying on a formula, and it seems to be following through on that promise wonderfully.
It's a solid return for one of the most underrated and understated comedies on television.

It's become comfortable and placid in a few storylines, but overall, the season 3 premiere of The Last Man on Earth retains the show's sharp, belly-laugh humor and suggests a wild season is coming down the line.
There are a few ok moments in the premiere and surely some great ones to come (last season's "Falling Slowly" duet was among the show's best), and for the Last Man faithful that may be enough.
The show is often so clever that it should satisfy those who require only a morsel of heart (or none at all) in their entertainment.
It's become warmer and more inviting without losing what made it special.
The show's original concept and the comedic sensibility of Forte, its series creator and star, give us confidence that the series will retain the funny, no matter which direction it ends up going.
I can see this being a big turn off for a mainstream audience, but I love just how far they're going here with pushing the boundaries of a what you'd see in a half hour network sitcom.
"Is There Anybody Out There?" very wisely returns to [its previous] mode, but with the added bonus of Phil having essentially turned Carol around to his ridiculous old way of living.
If we're going to be spending one-on-one time with Phil on such a small scale, we're going to need a little bit more growth to work with here - or we'd better go find Carol, ASAP.
Surprisingly, there's a lot of creative mileage to be had from poking at the genre without totally upending it.
The Last Man on Earth Season 2 Episode 1 was a very successful season opener that leaned on the series' undisputed strength - the amazing chemistry between Will Forte and Kristen Schaal.
As long as The Last Man on Earth keeps this level of storytelling up for the rest of the season, I will have no complaints.
The Last Man on Earth returns with the same winning ingredients, and maybe a little added depth to its margarita pool of post-apocalypse farce.

Forte - either by design all along or in reaction to Season 1 responses - consciously injects what was missing from Season 1 into the first two episodes of Season 2, but he does so without upsetting an alluring, already-established tone and world.
With its second season, Last Man on Earth needs to find a way to expand its outlook on its own universe, otherwise every episode this season will feel like a rerun of the first.
It can at least claim to be one of the more original new shows on television.
The apocalypse of Last Man is real, and Forte, Lord, and Miller aren't afraid to show the toll it's taken on both Phil and Carol in vastly different ways.
An ambitious and thoughtful comedy that features a great acting performance and asks viewers to ponder some big existential questions while giggling at the small-scale silly stuff.
With each episode, The Last Man On Earth becomes less original, less funny -- less the groundbreaker its most ardent supporters initially proclaimed it to be.
Credit for the success of this gambit falls largely to Schaal, who manages to transform the rather shrill rule-follower, harping on proper grammar and traffic laws, into engaging, funny company.
On the surface, the premise for Fox's new comedy The Last Man on Earth seems thin, but it turns out to remarkably durable and funny, at least for the first two episodes.

Much of the humor in The Last Man on Earth comes from the realization that humanity may well have to settle for these dregs in this start-over phase-unless there are more surprises ahead. Which is pretty much guaranteed. So lighten up and enjoy.

The Last Man on Earth is the rare broadcast show to both celebrate and embrace volatility... It's precisely the sort of thing you didn't know you wanted. And now it's impossible to imagine life without it.
The show's real charm will rely on the character chops of Forte and Schaal. Luckily, they seem up to the challenge.
At last, the apocalypse has acquired a sense of humor - and not the kind of humor you sometimes see in one of those zombie movies where catchphrases and snark alleviate the violence and gore.
Great character, inventive premise, clever production. The question is, would it have made a better movie than an ongoing series?
The only critic on Earth who doesn't like Fox's Last Man on Earth? You're reading her right now.
It's the most unusual new comedy of the year, and it's also one of the best.
If you can get through the depressing first half, there are a few laughs in the second episode.

Despite the incredibly dark premise, what distinguishes the early stages of The Last Man On Earth is the light and sure-footed way that a lot of obvious logical questions are totally ignored, while a lot of human questions are embraced and explored.
Forte projects an innate normality, an averageness and equanimity, that keeps his characters companionable, even at their most extravagant, astringent or abnormal.
The Last Man on Earth is the best last man on Earth take that I've seen in years.
The fact that it's different and ambitious... already makes Last Man more interesting than many new shows.
Watching Fox's wonderfully creative and ridiculously entertaining new series The Last Man on Earth, you can't help but laugh (it's a comedy - duh), but also be truly and utterly impressed.

Unfortunately, while the creative team gives it everything they have in the first two episodes, it's still difficult to see how the series can sustain over the course of a necessary 5-7 years or more.
Solid docu probes 2016 election, tries to be unbiased.
Whatever terrible revolution we're watching, it definitely isn't being televised with analysis and curiosity here.

Unlike coverage on Fox News or MSNBC, The Circus offers truly objective analysis of the campaigns. It also shows a more human side of the candidates, painting a clear picture of how grueling life is on the campaign trail.

The Circus is a kind of reassuring sanity break for politics nerds. There may be treacherous currents roiling this election, unknowable changes to come. But for one sharp half-hour every week, it's all just a show.

If anything The Circus represents merely another example of exalting the process of politics - the long bus trips, time spent time away from home and strategizing - without offering much that's new or compelling in terms of substance.
We're still only at the beginning stages. All the more reason to treasure an enterprise that preserves the small details as The Circus does.
It's by far the most cleverly shaped and enlightening coverage of U.S. politics right now.
Halperin and Heilemann, authors of the best-sellers Game Change and Double Down, certainly know their stuff, even if they inject themselves a little too enthusiastically into the proceedings.
Watching the show made me ache for the kind of candid, outraged political reportage that simply doesn't exist anymore.
The Frankenstein Chronicles might be hokum, but it's jolly good, rip-roaring hokum, oozing with Victorian gothic atmosphere and a heavily menacing air.
Gloomy 19th-century detective tale is clever but gory.
The shocks were mostly achieved by loud clangs of incidental music. An hour, and still no sign of the creature.
On balance, the season ended just as brilliantly grim as it started.
It has a solid period feel and a grubby menace, and a terrific cast led by Sean Bean.
Floating pig aside, not enough shows can claim a hero with the key characteristics: 'former soldier - dead wife and kids - nice hat - has syphilis'.
It's genuinely rather good, and a beast of wholly different hide to Jekyll.
It was bold, eerily effective and chillingly atmospheric. Bean's always a gruffly engaging screen presence and the all-star supporting cast was strong.
While it's unlikely to be remembered for as long as it took to make, Frankenstein certainly earned its shot at a long life on Netflix.
This show is full of layered allusions and references that all circle around the uneasy chicken-and-egg relationship that real life has with our nightmares.
